docs.title: Welcome to ScurryPy
docs.text: ScurryPy is a fully extensible foundation for Discord bots and frameworks. Build anything from a simple bot to a complete custom framework, with the architecture entirely up to you.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
ScurryPy is designed to be small, predictable, and transparent:

  • Lightweight core
  • Rate limit handling
  • Automatic session & gateway management
  • Automatic sharding
  • Predictable event models and resource classes

docs.title: Why ScurryPy?
docs.text:
ScurryPy is built on one idea: ✨clarity over magic ✨

  • Every operation is explicit
  • No hidden behavior or black boxes
  • Components do one job and do it predictably

This philosophy ensures that you can extend, compose, and control every part of your bot without hidden surprises.

If you want to understand your bot rather than fight it, you're in the right place.

docs.title: Extending ScurryPy
docs.text:
ScurryPy is intentionally minimal. You can build helpers, routers, command systems, and even entire frameworks on top of it.

However, certain core systems cannot be modified:

  • Gateway behavior
  • REST internals
  • Discord-enforced specifications
  • Event model definitions

These remain stable to ensure compliance with the Discord API.

For higher-level features such as decorators, routing, and stateful commands, consider ScurryKit — a framework built on top of ScurryPy.

docs.title: Helpful Links
docs.text:
• Getting Started - set up your first bot
  • Examples - practical demos and patterns
  • API - full function and class documentation
  • Events - event objects and signatures
  • Resources - REST resource helpers
  • Internals - how ScurryPy works internally

docs.title: Doc Footnotes
docs.text:
This section details footnotes that appear throughout the source code. Footnotes are introduced to ScurryPy to make inconsistencies with Discord's docs known.

Footnotes are always formatted as: 

    my_field: type
    """My description. [`MY_FOOTNOTE`][`ANOTHER_NOTE`]"""

docs.title: INT_LIMIT
docs.text: Discord sends some numbers as strings due to JSON integer precision limits. But this is not a limit of Python, so these fields will be marked int, and therefore, converted to integers.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
The following example demonstrates what it looks like to use of ScurryPy itself.

Building Beyond ScurryPy

These examples demonstrate the idiomatic and recommended patterns for working with ScurryPy. They are intended to illustrate how the core API is designed to be used before introducing additional abstractions.

Setting Up

These examples assume you've already seen Setting Up.

docs.title: Minimal Event Listener
docs.text:
Drop-in example demonstrating listening for the READY event.

class MyAddon:
    def __init__(self, client: scurrypy.Client):

        self.bot = client

        # register this addon's functions to the client
        client.add_event_listener('READY', self.on_ready)

    async def on_ready(self, event: scurrypy.ReadyEvent):
        self.bot.logger.log_info("Bot is ready!")

client = scurrypy.Client(token=TOKEN, application_id=APP_ID)

# register addon with client
my_addon = MyAddon(client)

client.run()

docs.title: Minimal Addon
docs.text:
Demonstrates addon setup. Feel free to use this as a reference!

ScurryPy's Contract

ScurryPy validates handler signatures at registration time, catching errors before your bot runs. Each registration method expects specific parameters:

  • client.add_event_listener → def handler(self, event) (sync or async)
  • client.add_startup_hook → def handler(self) (sync or async)
  • client.add_shutdown_hook → def handler(self) (sync or async)

If signatures don't match, ScurryPy raises an error immediately. This prevents bugs from reaching production!

class MyAddon:
    """Your custom addon."""

    def __init__(self, client: scurrypy.Client):
        self.bot = client

        # register handlers - validated immediately!
        client.add_startup_hook(self.my_opening_handler)
        client.add_event_listener('DISCORD_EVENT', self.my_event_listener)
        client.add_shutdown_hook(self.my_closing_handler)

    def my_opening_handler(self):  # can be sync or async
        """Custom startup hooks."""
        self.bot.logger.log_info("Starting up!")

    async def my_event_listener(self, event):
        """Handle your event here!"""
        self.bot.logger.log_info(f"Got event: {event.name}")

    def my_closing_handler(self):
        """Custom shutdown hooks."""
        self.bot.logger.log_info("Shutting down!")

About Addons

Addons only add convenient patterns and never change the Discord API itself. You can optionally use Addon as a marker or typing convenience.

docs.title: Event Routing
docs.text:
Demonstrates listening to multiple events in one addon.

class MyAddon:
    def __init__(self, client: Client):
        self.bot = client

        client.add_event_listener('GUILD_CREATE', self.on_guild_create)
        client.add_event_listener('GUILD_DELETE', self.on_guild_delete)

        client.add_event_listener('CHANNEL_CREATE', self.on_channel_create)
        client.add_event_listener('CHANNEL_UPDATE', self.on_channel_update)
        client.add_event_listener('CHANNEL_DELETE', self.on_channel_delete)

    def on_guild_create(self, event: GuildCreateEvent):
        """Handle something on guild create."""

    def on_guild_delete(self, event: GuildDeleteEvent):
        """Handle something on guild delete."""

    def on_channel_create(self, event: GuildChannelCreateEvent):
        """Handle something on channel create."""

    def on_channel_update(self, event: GuildChannelUpdateEvent):
        """Handle something on channel update."""

    def on_channel_delete(self, event: GuildChannelDeleteEvent):
        """Handle something on channel delete."""

docs.title: Using Decorators
docs.text:
Demonstrates registering and listening to messages for commands via the MESSAGE_CREATE event.

Command handler signatures are proactively checked by the decorator.

class MyAddon:
    def __init__(self, client: scurrypy.Client, prefix: str):

        if not scurrypy.Intents.has(client.intents, scurrypy.Intents.MESSAGE_CONTENT):
            raise ValueError("Missing Intent.MESSAGE_CONTENT for scanning messages.")

        self.bot = client

        self.prefix = prefix
        self.commands = {}

        # fill contract with client
        client.add_event_listener("MESSAGE_CREATE", self.on_message_create)

    async def on_message_create(self, event: scurrypy.MessageCreateEvent):
        """Your message prefix logic"""

    def prefix(self, name: str):
        """Decorator for registering prefix command handlers."""
        # make commands case-insensitive
        cmd = name.lower()

        def decorator(func):
            import inspect
            params_len = len(inspect.signature(func).parameters) # control parameters here
            if params_len != 2:
                raise ValueError(f"Prefix command '{cmd}' expects parameters (bot, message).")
            self.commands[cmd] = func

        self.bot.logger.log_info(f"Prefix command '{cmd}' registered!")

        return decorator

client = scurrypy.Client(
    token=TOKEN, 
    application_id=APP_ID, 
    intents=scurrypy.Intents.set(message_content=True)
)

my_addon = MyAddon(client, '!')

@my_addon.prefix("ping")
async def on_ping(bot: scurrypy.Client, message: scurrypy.Message):
    await message.send('Pong!')

client.run()

docs.title: Basic Slash Command
docs.text:
Drop-in example demonstrating registering and responding to a slash command.

class MyAddon:
    def __init__(self, client: scurrypy.Client):
        self.bot = client

        self.slash_commands = {}

        client.add_startup_hook(self.on_start)
        client.add_event_listener("INTERACTION_CREATE", self.on_interaction)

    async def on_start(self):
        """Register commands and routes."""

        commands = [
            scurrypy.SlashCommand('hello', 'Say hello!')
        ]

        await self.bot.register_guild_commands(commands, guild_id=GUILD_ID)

        self.slash_commands['hello'] = self.on_hello

        self.bot.logger.log_info("Commands ready!")

    async def on_hello(self, interaction: scurrypy.Interaction):
        """Demo interaction response."""

        await interaction.respond("You got it!")

    async def on_interaction(self, event: scurrypy.InteractionEvent):
        """Handles routing event by interaction type."""
        if event.type != scurrypy.InteractionTypes.APPLICATION_COMMAND:
            return

        handler = self.slash_commands.get(event.data.name)

        res = self.bot.interaction(event.id, event.token, context=event)
        if handler:
            await handler(res)
        else:
            await res.respond("Command not found!", ephemeral=True)

client = scurrypy.Client(token=TOKEN, application_id=APP_ID)

my_addon = MyAddon(client)

client.run()

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to the getting started section! This page will help you install ScurryPy, set up your environment, and get ready to build your first bot.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
If you haven't already, you can install ScurryPy with pip:

pip install scurrypy

That's all you need. No extra dependencies.

docs.title: Setting up
docs.text:
In your main bot file, it’s recommended to load your environment variables and prepare your constants:

import scurrypy, os, dotenv

# Load environment variables (optional but recommended)
dotenv.load_dotenv("path/to/.env")

TOKEN = os.getenv("BOT_TOKEN") # your bot token
APP_ID = ... # your application ID
GUILD_ID = ... # your guild ID (optional, for guild commands)

You’re now ready to start using ScurryPy!

docs.title: Next Steps...
docs.text:
• Examples - examples covering events, routing, commands, and more
  • API - detailed class and method documentation
  • Events - all event objects and structures
  • Resources - request helpers for interacting with Discord’s REST API

docs.title: Welcome to the API section!
docs.text:
This section covers the high-level objects. It provides entry-level classes for building a bot such as the client, registering commands and event listeners, and accessing Discord resources.

  • Client - main entry point for discord bot.
  • Intents - specify what events you want your bot to receive.
  • Commands - register and runs commands and event handlers.
  • UI Components - tools for building Discord's new component setup.
  • Components - register and runs component handlers.
  • Message - tools for building a message.
  • Models - dataclasses mimicing Discord's payload structure for dot access.
  • Role - layout for building a role.
  • Embed (Legacy) - tools for adding embedded content within a message.

docs.title: to_dict
docs.text:
EXCEPTION to the "models contain no custom methods" rule for two reasons:

  1. to_dict already exists on all models via inheritance, so overriding it does not break the design model.

  2. Thumbnail (Component V2) and EmbedThumbnail (Embed-only) are extremely easy to confuse. This guard catches the mistake early and provides a clear, actionable error instead of allowing Discord to return an obscure 400 error.

docs.title: Intents
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.core.intents module.

Important

For unverified bots, privileged intents can only be used if your bot is in less than 100 guilds! Otherwise, your bot needs to be verified to use these intents.

docs.title: Intents
docs.text:
Gateway intent flags (bitwise). For an exhaustive list what intents let your bot listen to what events, see list of intents.

Note

Not all intents are listed. Intents not listed are not yet supported.

docs.title: GUILDS = 1 << 0 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events related to guilds.

docs.title: GUILD_MEMBERS = 1 << 1 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text:
Privileged Intent

Requires the app setting Server Members Intent to be toggled.

Receive events related to guild members.

docs.title: GUILD_EMOJIS_AND_STICKERS = 1 << 3 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events related to custom emojis and stickers.

docs.title: GUILD_INTEGRATIONS = 1 << 4 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events related to integrations within a guild.

docs.title: GUILD_WEBHOOKS = 1 << 5 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Track webhook events within a guild.

docs.title: GUILD_MESSAGES = 1 << 9 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Receive events about messages within a guild.

docs.title: GUILD_MESSAGE_REACTIONS = 1 << 10 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Track changes in reactions on messages.

docs.title: MESSAGE_CONTENT = 1 << 15 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text:
Privileged Intent

Requires the app setting Message Content Intent to be toggled.

Access content of messages.

docs.title: set staticmethod
docs.text:
Set bot intents. See Intents. Intents.DEFAULT will also be set.

Parameters:

  • **flags (Unpack[IntentFlagParams], default: {} ) –

    intents to set

Raises:

  • ValueError –

    invalid flag

Returns:

  • int –

    combined intents field

docs.title: has staticmethod
docs.text:
Checks if an intent bit is toggled.

Parameters:

  • intents (int) –

    bot intents

  • intent (int) –

    intent bit to check

Returns:

  • bool –

    if intent bit is toggled

docs.title: IntentFlagParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Gateway intent selection parameters.

Important

Param name MUST match the intent it represents! For example, "GUILD_MESSAGES" is "guild_messages".

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.core.permissions module.

docs.title: Permissions
docs.text:
Guild/User permission flags.

Note

Not all permissions are listed. Permissions not listed are not yet supported.

docs.title: CREATE_INSTANT_INVITE = 1 << 0 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows creation of instant invites.

docs.title: KICK_MEMBERS = 1 << 1 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows kicking members.

docs.title: BAN_MEMBERS = 1 << 2 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows banning members.

docs.title: ADMINISTRATOR = 1 << 3 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows all permissions and bypasses channel permission overwrites.

docs.title: MANAGE_CHANNELS = 1 << 4 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows management and editing of channels

docs.title: MANAGE_GUILD = 1 << 5 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows management and editing of the guild.

docs.title: ADD_REACTIONS = 1 << 6 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text:
Allows for adding new reactions to messages.

Warning

This permission does not apply to reacting with an existing reaction on a message.

docs.title: VIEW_CHANNEL = 1 << 10 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows guild members to view a channel, which includes reading messages in text channels and joining voice channels.

docs.title: SEND_MESSAGES = 1 << 11 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text:
Allows for sending messages in a channel and creating threads in a forum.

Warning

Does not allow sending messages in threads.

docs.title: MANAGE_MESSAGES = 1 << 13 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for deletion of other users messages.

docs.title: EMBED_LINKS = 1 << 14 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Links sent by users with this permission will be auto-embedded.

docs.title: ATTACH_FILES = 1 << 15 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for uploading images and files.

docs.title: READ_MESSAGE_HISTORY = 1 << 16 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for reading of message history.

docs.title: USE_EXTERNAL_EMOJIS = 1 << 18 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows the usage of custom emojis from other servers.

docs.title: MANAGE_ROLES = 1 << 28 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows management and editing of roles.

docs.title: USE_APPLICATION_COMMANDS = 1 << 31 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows members to use application commands, including slash commands and context menu commands.

docs.title: MANAGE_THREADS = 1 << 34 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for deleting and archiving threads, and viewing all private threads.

docs.title: CREATE_PUBLIC_THREADS = 1 << 35 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for creating public and announcement threads.

docs.title: CREATE_PRIVATE_THREADS = 1 << 36 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for creating private threads.

docs.title: SEND_MESSAGES_IN_THREADS = 1 << 38 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for sending messages in threads.

docs.title: MODERATE_MEMBERS = 1 << 40 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows for timing out users to prevent them from sending or reacting to messages in chat and threads, and from speaking in voice and stage channels.

docs.title: SEND_POLLS = 1 << 49 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows sending polls.

docs.title: PIN_MESSAGES = 1 << 51 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows pinning and unpinning messages.

docs.title: BYPASS_SLOWMODE = 1 << 52 class-attribute instance-attribute
docs.text: Allows bypassing slowmode restrictions.

docs.title: Welcome to the Events section!
docs.text:
This section is dedicated to the modeling of Discord's event payloads. Events are sent back when an event your bot is listening for is triggered (see Gateway Intents for more). These classes themselves have no methods and are used purely for reference.

  • Interaction - events related to interactions.
  • Message - events related to messages.
  • Channel - events related to channels.
  • Guild - events related to guilds.
  • Reaction - events related to reactions.
  • Ready - the READY event sent when the bot goes online.

docs.title: Channel Events
docs.text:
Note

Internal API

These classes are for internal use only.

Users should interact with Client and other public API classes instead.

This warning will be at the top of every page.

docs.title: Lost? Head back to the Landing Page, silly!
docs.text:
This section is dedicated to internal classes and structures. These classes work underneath the public interface and are not meant to be touched by the average user.

Any breaks that occur from attempting to use the internals as a way of overriding default behavior is not a fault of this library!

Proceed at your own risk!

  • Data Model - parent class for hydrating child dataclasses with Discord's response payloads.
  • HTTP - HTTP client session tools for managing HTTP requests with Discord with built-in rate limiting.
  • Gateway - websocket tools for managing a websocket connection with Discord.
  • Logger - logging tools for logging events.
  • Discord Error - models Discord's API error structure and outputs a more readable message.

docs.title: Technical Writeup
docs.text: ScurryPy is a discord API wrapper written in Python that aims to provide clarity over magic. While this may seem straightforward at first glance, especially when other libraries have already implemented it, there are plenty of technical accomplishments that help ScurryPy stand out from other trending libraries; most notably, the core is under 1000 lines of code.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
So what makes ScurryPy so effective? Caching? No. ScurryPy does not assume what the user needs nor does it try to guess what the user wants to do. Avoiding circular imports with annotations? Nope. All classes have clearly set boundaries for what they do so there is no need for annotations. As a result, ScurryPy is modular in that it provides you with the building blocks, and you do what you want with them (guided by Discord’s API). These are just the highlights of what clarity over magic can bring to the table.

This writeup will cover the main parts of ScurryPy including the HTTP and rate limiting, Gateway logic and sharding, and how the Client glues this all together without being a god object. Don’t let the terms intimidate you. Each section will have a mental map to help visualize steps. By the end of this writeup, you'll understand how clarity over magic leads to better software - and how to implement Discord's most notoriously difficult features.

docs.title: HTTP Client
docs.text:
Before digging in with the HTTP Client, this section, and future sections, will lead with a mental map to help guide the explanation.

Figure 1: HTTP Client Mental Map

The HTTP Client is responsible for queuing and sending requests. That’s it. No fancy abstractions. No layers of indirection. Just. Sending and documenting the requests. This sets up independence such that when adding an endpoint, fire a request and think of nothing else. If it’s a GET request, expect data to return. ScurryPy marks all GET endpoints with fetch_{object}. The client takes the parameters you’d expect to need to make a request, like endpoint and method, and spits back out the JSON object from Discord.

Now, let’s go through the map step by step:

  1. Send request via GET to endpoint, say, “channels/123/messages”
  2. The request is put into a queue based on this endpoint with a lock.
    • A lock coordinates updates to the dictionary that maps endpoints to their queues.
    • Each queue has a dedicated worker to handle the request.
  3. The worker sends the HTTP request and waits for Discord's response.
  4. Using the bucket ID from Discord's response, update or create the bucket's rate limit info (with proper lock coordination).
    • A lock coordinates lock access itself and then a lock per bucket ID.
    • If the rate limit is exhausted (no remaining requests), then create a sleep task. This is proactive rate limiting so no 429 is returned.
    • If another request targets the same bucket, it waits for the sleep task to finish.

Done.

Key Idea: Each endpoint gets its own queue and worker, and each worker enforces proactive rate limiting using Discord’s bucket replies.

docs.title: Gateway Client
docs.text:
Gateway is more straightforward. Let’s start with the mental map.

Figure 2: Gateway Client Mental Map

The Gateway Client is self-sufficient in that it handles its own connection (or shard) to the Gateway. That is all this client is for. The beauty of this design is that sharding is the matter of spawning the needed number of shards at the rate of the max concurrency as recommended by Discord. What if you need to access a specific shard or know what event a shard came from? Not a problem! Use Discord’s formula: (guild_id >> 22) % shard_count.

Let’s dig into the steps of the mental map:

  1. Connect to the gateway with the URL provided by the GET /gateway/bot endpoint and use the URL params “?v=10&encoding=json”. URL params set the stage for how Discord should send its data packets. In this case, the URL signals using JSON encoding: Discord serializes events as JSON strings to be deserialized into Python dictionaries.
  2. Await the HELLO event Discord sends back when you connect.
    • Use this to set heartbeat intervals and initialize the sequence number.
    • This is when the heartbeat task is started to keep the session alive. Fire-and-forget.
  3. Send IDENTIFY through the websocket.
  4. That’s it for new shards or connections. At this point, it’s about listening to certain OP codes. Only OP codes that impact the connection state are listed.
    • OP 0: dispatch. Enqueue this for the Client to pick up.
    • OP 7: a disconnect occurred and Discord wants you to RESUME.
    • OP 9: a disconnect occurred causing the session to be invalid. Discord wants you to start fresh.

Done. This is the minimal set of logic required to maintain a stable gateway connection.

Key Idea: Each connection or shard gets its own task to connect, identify, reconnect or re-identify if needed, listen to events, and eventually close.

docs.title: Bot Client
docs.text:
Almost there, if you’ve read this far, you’re doing great! Know that from here on out, it’s dead simple. The mental map for the Bot Client looks something like:

Figure 3: Bot Client Mental Map

The Bot Client is intentionally not a god object. It is really just an orchestrator - it uses the HTTP and Gateway clients you've already seen. There are parts that were left out of the map such as the decorators to register commands and resource fetching helpers so the user doesn’t have to touch the HTTP Client directly. But let’s be honest, connection logic is the meat of the Bot Client. And that’s all. Let’s go through the mental map step by step:

  1. Start the HTTP Client. No strings attached.
  2. Run setup hooks. This is an array of callable functions that the user can set using the “setup_hook” decorators. These hooks run once for the entire life cycle of the bot. Need to start a database? This is where you do it!
  3. Sync slash commands (guild and global). This is just toggled with a setting in the Bot Client’s constructor for convenience.
  4. Fetch the gateway info. This is where important start up info is located such as the total number of recommended shards, how many shards can be started concurrently, and the recommended gateway connect URL.
  5. Then based on the gateway info, as shards start up, fire a task to listen to each shard.This is a task per shard and each shard has its own event queue so the listener doesn’t need to know anything about what shard it is, just direct the event accordingly. Listening and starting occur concurrently. So as shards are starting up, the shards already started can start taking in events as soon as they’re ready. The “sleep 5 seconds” is waiting per batch to not spam Discord’s gateway.

Done.

Key Idea: The Client's sole purpose is to provide a thin abstraction layer between internals and the user-facing API.

docs.title: Data Model
docs.text:
The final piece: how to turn Discord's JSON into clean, type-safe Python objects. DataModel is a class that transforms Discord's JSON into usable Python objects and back again when needed. A user could just access the dictionary itself, sure. But, what if dictionaries could be represented as a class so instead of event[‘data’], it looks like event.data? This is where the DataModel class comes in. Let’s take a look at the mental map

Figure 4: Data Model Mental Map

This one is straightforward. Let’s dig into the step by step:

  1. The from_dict function hydrates a dataclass by iterating over its fields and pulling matching values from Discord's JSON payload. If a field isn't in the payload, it's skipped; no guessing. The result? Clean dot notation (event.data) instead of dictionary access (event['data']).
  2. When you need to send data back to Discord, to_dict does the reverse: converts the dataclass attributes back into a dictionary.

Done.

You might be wondering: what about nested objects like a Message containing a User? DataModel handles that recursively. It calls from_dict or to_dict on child DataModels automatically.

Key Idea: This DataModel class exists to deserialize Discord's payloads and serialize dataclasses for fluent communication between ScurryPy and Discord.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: Because every subsystem is small, explicit, and self-contained, extending ScurryPy is almost trivial: add a model, add a resource, and use the HTTP client directly. You can prototype new Discord features the day they release, build custom caching, or omit caching entirely. The library never fights you; it never assumes what you want. That’s the benefit of clarity over magic.

docs.title: Welcome to the Resources section!
docs.text:
This section is dedicated to modeling Discord's resources. These resources represent an object with methods to interact with itself. Resources need to be requested unless the resource is part of the event object. Resources act as a thin layer over the HTTP client handling requests internally. See Events for event-related details.

  • Interaction - the interaction resource. This is where you respond to interactions.
  • Message - the message resource. This is where you can create, edit, and delete a message.
  • User - the user resource. This is where you can fetch information about a user or guild member.
  • Channel - the channel resource. This is where you can create, edit, and delete a channel.
  • Guild - the guild resource. This is where you can fetch information about a guild.
  • Bot Emojis - data pertaining to bot-owned emojis. Treated like a resource.
  • Application - the application resource. This is where you can fetch information about an application.

docs.title: Application Resource
docs.text:

Bases: BaseResource

Represents a Discord Bot Emoji.

docs.title: application_id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Application ID of the emojis.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetch an emoji from the bot repository.

Parameters:

  • emoji_id (int) –

    emoji ID

  • EmojiModel –

Fetch all emojis from the bot repository.

docs.title: Channel Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.channel module.

docs.title: Channel dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: BaseResource

Represents a Discord guild channel.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the channel.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetch the full channel data from Discord.

Returns:

  • ChannelModel –

    A new Channel object with all fields populated

docs.title: fetch_messages async
docs.text:
Fetches this channel's messages.

Permissions
  • VIEW_CHANNEL → required to access channel messages
  • READ_MESSAGE_HISTORY → required for user, otherwise no messages are returned

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[MessagesFetchParams], default: {} ) –

    message fetch params

    Note

    if no kwargs are provided, default to 50 fetched messages limit.

Returns:

  • list[MessageModel] –

    queried messages

docs.title: send async
docs.text:
Send a message to this channel.

Permissions
  • SEND_MESSAGES → required to create a message in this channel

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    can be just text or the MessagePart for dynamic messages

Returns:

  • MessageModel –

    The created Message object

docs.title: edit async
docs.text:
Edit this channel's settings.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_CHANNELS → required to edit this channel

Parameters:

  • channel (GuildChannel) –

    channel changes

Returns:

  • ChannelModel –

    The updated channel object

docs.title: create_thread_from_message async
docs.text:
Create a thread from this message

Parameters:

  • message_id (int) –

    ID of message to attach thread

  • name (str) –

    thread name

  • **kwargs (Unpack[ThreadFromMessageParams], default: {} ) –

    thread create params

Returns:

  • ChannelModel –

    The updated channel object

docs.title: fetch_pins async
docs.text:
Get this channel's pinned messages.

Permissions
  • VIEW_CHANNEL → required to access pinned messages
  • READ_MESSAGE_HISTORY → required for reading pinned messages

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[PinsFetchParams], default: {} ) –

    pinned message fetch params

    Note

    If no kwargs are provided, default to 50 fetched messages limit.

Returns:

  • list[PinnedMessage] –

    list of pinned messages

docs.title: delete async
docs.text:
Deletes this channel from the server.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_CHANNELS → required to delete this channel

docs.title: PinsFetchParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Params when fetching pinned messages.

docs.title: before: str instance-attribute
docs.text: Get pinned messages before this ISO8601 timestamp.

docs.title: limit: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Max number of pinned messages to return. Range 1 - 50. Default 50.

docs.title: MessagesFetchParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Params when fetching guild channel messages.

docs.title: limit: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Max number of messages to return. Range 1 - 100. Default 50.

docs.title: before: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get messages before this message ID.

docs.title: after: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get messages after this message ID.

docs.title: around: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get messages around this message ID.

docs.title: ThreadFromMessageParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Params when attaching a thread to a message.

docs.title: rate_limit_per_user: int instance-attribute
docs.text: time (seconds) user waits before sending another message.

docs.title: Guild Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.guild module.

docs.title: Guild dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: BaseResource

Represents a Discord guild.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the guild.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetch the Guild object by the given ID.

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[FetchGuildParams], default: {} ) –

    guild fetch params

    Note

    If no kwargs are provided, default to with_counts = False

Returns:

  • GuildModel –

    the Guild object

docs.title: fetch_channels async
docs.text:
Fetch this guild's channels.

Returns:

  • list[ChannelModel] –

    list of the guild's channels

docs.title: create_channel async
docs.text:
Create a channel in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_CHANNELS → required to create a channel

Parameters:

  • channel (GuildChannel) –

    the buildable guild channel

Returns:

  • ChannelModel –

    the created channel

docs.title: fetch_guild_member async
docs.text:
Fetch a member in this guild.

Important

Requires the GUILD_MEMBERS privileged intent!

Parameters:

  • user_id (int) –

    user ID of the member to fetch

Returns:

  • GuildMemberModel –

    member's data

docs.title: fetch_guild_members async
docs.text:
Fetch guild members in this guild.

Important

Requires the GUILD_MEMBERS privileged intent!

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[FetchGuildMembersParams], default: {} ) –

    guild members fetch params

    Note

    If no kwargs are provided, default to 1 guild member limit.

Returns:

  • list[GuildMemberModel] –

    list of member data

docs.title: add_guild_member_role async
docs.text:
Append a role to a guild member of this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to add a role to the user

Parameters:

  • user_id (int) –

    ID of the member for the role

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of the role to append

docs.title: remove_guild_member_role async
docs.text:
Remove a role from a guild member of this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to remove a role from the user

Parameters:

  • user_id (int) –

    ID of the member with the role

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of the role to remove

docs.title: fetch_guild_role async
docs.text:
Fetch a role in this guild.

Parameters:

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of the role to fetch

Returns:

  • RoleModel –

    fetched role's data

docs.title: fetch_guild_roles async
docs.text:
Fetch all roles in this guild.

Returns:

  • list[RoleModel] –

    list of fetched roles' data

docs.title: create_guild_role async
docs.text:
Create a role in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to add a role to the guild

Parameters:

  • role (Role) –

    role to create

Returns:

  • RoleModel –

    new role data

docs.title: modify_guild_role async
docs.text:
Modify a role in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to modify a role in the guild

Parameters:

  • role (Role) –

    role with changes

Returns:

  • RoleModel –

    role with changes

docs.title: delete_guild_role async
docs.text:
Delete a role in this guild.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_ROLES → required to delete a role in the guild

Parameters:

  • role_id (int) –

    ID of role to delete

docs.title: FetchGuildParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Params when fetching a guild.

docs.title: with_counts: Optional[bool] instance-attribute
docs.text: If True, return the approximate member and presence counts for the guild.

docs.title: FetchGuildMembersParams
docs.text:
Bases: TypedDict

Params when fetching guild members.

docs.title: limit: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Max number of members to return Range 1 - 1000. Default 1.

docs.title: after: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Highest user ID in previous page.

docs.title: Guild Emojis Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.guild_emoji module.

docs.title: GuildEmoji dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: BaseResource

Represents a Discord Guild Emoji.

docs.title: guild_id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Guild ID of the emojis.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetch an emoji from a guild.

Parameters:

  • emoji_id (int) –

    emoji ID

Returns:

  • EmojiModel –

    the Emoji object

docs.title: fetch_all async
docs.text:
Fetch all emojis from a guild.

Returns:

  • list[EmojiModel] –

    queried guild emojis

docs.title: Interaction Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.interaction module.

docs.title: Interaction dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: BaseResource

Represents a Discord Interaction object.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the interaction.

docs.title: token: str instance-attribute
docs.text: Continuation token for responding to the interaction.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: respond async
docs.text:
Create a message in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    content as a string or MessagePart

  • with_response (bool, default: False ) –

    if the interaction data should be returned. Defaults to False.

  • **flags (Unpack[MessageFlagParams], default: {} ) –

    message flags to set. (set respective flag to True to toggle.)

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid message type

Returns:

  • InteractionCallbackModel | None –

    interaction callback object (if with_response is toggled) else None

docs.title: update async
docs.text:
Update a message in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    content as a string or MessagePart

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid message type

docs.title: respond_modal async
docs.text:
Create a modal in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • modal (ModalPart) –

    modal data

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid modal type

docs.title: respond_autocomplete async
docs.text:
Autocomplete a command in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • choices (list[CommandOptionChoice]) –

    list of choices to autocomplete

docs.title: defer_respond async
docs.text:
Defer creating a message in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • ephemeral (bool) –

    whether thinking + deferred interaction response is ephemeral

docs.title: defer_update async
docs.text:
Defer updating a message in response to an interaction.

Parameters:

  • ephemeral (bool) –

    whether the deferred interaction response is ephemeral

docs.title: followup async
docs.text:
Create a new message to respond to a deferred interaction.

Important

Apps are limited to 5 followup messages PER interaction.

Parameters:

  • application_id (int) –

    ID of the application

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    content as a string or MessagePart

  • **flags (Unpack[MessageFlagParams], default: {} ) –

    message flags to set. (set respective flag to True to toggle.)

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid message type

docs.title: edit_original async
docs.text:
Update the original interaction response from a deferred update interaction.

Parameters:

  • application_id (int) –

    ID of the application

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    content as a string or MessagePart

Raises:

  • TypeError –

    invalid message type

docs.title: Message Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.message module.

docs.title: Message dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: BaseResource

A Discord message.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the message

docs.title: channel_id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Channel ID of the message.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetches the message data based on the given channel ID and message id.

Returns:

  • MessageModel –

    the message object

docs.title: send async
docs.text:
Sends a new message to the current channel.

Permissions
  • SEND_MESSAGES → required to senf your own messages

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    can be just text or the MessagePart for dynamic messages

Returns:

  • MessageModel –

    the new Message object with all fields populated

docs.title: edit async
docs.text:
Edits this message.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → ONLY if editing another user's message

Parameters:

  • message (str | MessagePart) –

    can be just text or the MessagePart for dynamic messages

Returns:

  • MessageModel –

    the edited message

docs.title: crosspost async
docs.text:
Crosspost this message in an Annoucement channel to all following channels.

Permissions
  • SEND_MESSAGES → required to publish your own messages
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → required to publish messages from others

Returns:

  • MessageModel –

    the published (crossposted) message

docs.title: delete async
docs.text: Deletes this message.

docs.title: add_reaction async
docs.text:
Add a reaction from this message.

Permissions
  • READ_MESSAGE_HISTORY → required to view message
  • ADD_REACTIONS → required to create reaction

Parameters:

  • emoji (EmojiModel | str) –

    the standard emoji (str) or custom emoji (EmojiModel)

docs.title: remove_reaction async
docs.text:
Remove the bot's reaction from this message.

Parameters:

  • emoji (EmojiModel | str) –

    the standard emoji (str) or custom emoji (EmojiModel)

docs.title: remove_user_reaction async
docs.text:
Remove a specific user's reaction from this message.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → required to remove another user's reaction

Parameters:

  • emoji (EmojiModel | str) –

    the standard emoji (str) or custom emoji (EmojiModel)

  • user_id (int) –

    user's ID

docs.title: remove_all_reactions async
docs.text:
Clear all reactions from this message.

Permissions
  • MANAGE_MESSAGES → required to remove all reaction

docs.title: pin async
docs.text: Pin this message to its channel's pins.

docs.title: unpin async
docs.text: Unpin this message from its channel's pins.

docs.title: User Resource
docs.text:
Note

The following classes come from the scurrypy.resources.user module.

docs.title: User dataclass
docs.text:
Bases: BaseResource

A Discord user.

docs.title: id: int instance-attribute
docs.text: ID of the user.

docs.title: context: Any instance-attribute
docs.text: Associated user data.

docs.title: fetch async
docs.text:
Fetch this user by ID.

Note

Fetch includes both /users/@me AND /users/{user.id}!

Returns:

  • UserModel –

    the User object

docs.title: fetch_guilds async
docs.text:
Fetch this user's guilds.

Important

Requires the OAuth2 guilds scope!

Parameters:

  • **kwargs (Unpack[FetchUserGuildsParams], default: {} ) –

    user guilds fetch params

    Note

    If no kwargs are provided, default to 200 guilds limit.

Returns:

  • list[GuildModel] –

    each guild's data

docs.title: fetch_guild_member async
docs.text:
Fetch this user's guild member data.

Important

Requires the OAuth2 guilds.members.read scope!

Parameters:

  • guild_id (int) –

    ID of guild to fetch data from

Returns:

  • GuildMemberModel –

    member data from guild

docs.title: FetchUserGuildsParams
docs.text: Bases: TypedDict

docs.title: before: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get guilds before this guild ID.

docs.title: after: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Get guilds after this guild ID.

docs.title: limit: int instance-attribute
docs.text: Max number of guilds to return. Range 1 - 200. Default 200.

docs.title: with_counts: bool instance-attribute
docs.text: Include approximate member and presence count.
